physical_appearance:This is a gold ornament of Shou Lau
 the God of Longevity
 riding a crane. He is depicted smiling
 in an intricately designed robe
 facing forward. The crane\u0027s wings are outstretched on either side. Small clouds and birds are attached to the main structure by coiled springs.

sgcool_label_text:This is an ornament of Shou Lau riding a crane. He is the God of Longevity and is often depicted with a crane
 also a potent symbol of longevity. It is likely that this ornament was originally sewn onto a textile such as a ceremonial handkerchief or a wedding headband. Based on the shopmark on the reverse of the ornament
 this was made by Da Xing (??)
 one of the popular goldsmiths commissioned by Peranakans in the Straits to produce their jewellery and silverware.\r\n\r\nThis ornament is part of a group donation from descendants of Tan Kim Seng and Tan Jiak Kim. Both were wealthy merchants
 philanthropists and leaders of the local Hokkien community.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a gold ornament of Shou Lau, the God of Longevity, riding a crane. He is depicted smiling, in an intricately designed robe, facing forward. The crane's wings are outstretched on either side. Small clouds and birds are attached to the main structure by coiled springs.
metadata.subject_terms_1: birds (motifs) deities depictions (visual works) commissions (orders for works)
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This is an ornament of Shou Lau riding a crane. He is the God of Longevity and is often depicted with a crane, also a potent symbol of longevity. It is likely that this ornament was originally sewn onto a textile such as a ceremonial handkerchief or a wedding headband. Based on the shopmark on the reverse of the ornament, this was made by Da Xing (??), one of the popular goldsmiths commissioned by Peranakans in the Straits to produce their jewellery and silverware.

This ornament is part of a group donation from descendants of Tan Kim Seng and Tan Jiak Kim. Both were wealthy merchants, philanthropists and leaders of the local Hokkien community.
